msContents.summary: Receipt for 13 drachmae paid by Dionysius, son of Didymus, to the tax-farmer, Sarapion.

msItemStruct.note: Text is on one side only, 8 lines written with the fibers. The first 5-6 lines are in one hand, the remaining lines are in a second hand. Top and bottom marins clearly visible. Text mentions the village of Theadelphia.
Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology collection

supportDesc.support: 8.7 x 8.4cm. The left and right margins are badly damaged, with the result that some writing is missing. The top line is also broken due to a large horizontal tear. The bottom margin is torn, but no writing appears to be affected.

provenance.p: Excavated by Grenfell and Hunt (1898-9) on behalf of the Egyptian Exploration Fund, and donated to the University Museum in return for its support (1901, Dr. Parrish Collection).

taxonomy.desc: APIS keywords are controlled locally at the institution level. They are not necessarily consistent.

div.ab: The 18th year of the Aurelii Antoninus and Commodus the lords Augusti, Epeiph 6. Paid to Sarapion, farmer of the tax on cutting and trade, by Dionysius, son of Didymus, of the Linen-factories' quarter, living at the village of Theadelphia, for the trade-tax of the same year, eight drachmae of silver on account, total 8 dr. Also in the 19th year, Athur 13, paid on account of the preceding 18th year, through Isidorus, assistant, five drachmae...obols and a half more. (Grenfell, Hunt & Hogarth)
